Situation1: They remain cheerful and patient while handling an upset customer during a peak holiday rush.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: Officials ask voters with last names A–M to move to a newly opened line, even though the original line is moving faster.
Story: The store is packed, the holiday rush in full swing, and I’m behind the register, trying to keep my smile steady as a customer in front of me complains about a missing discount. My manager’s words echo in my head: “Stay friendly, no matter what.” I nod, apologize, and promise to fix the issue, even as the line behind her grows longer and more impatient. My phone buzzes in my pocket—a reminder that I need to vote before my shift ends. I finally clock out and rush to the polling station, only to find a long line snaking out the door. I join it, relieved to be almost done with the day. Suddenly, an official calls out, “If your last name starts with A through M, please move to the new line!” The new line is longer, but the official insists. I hesitate, torn. As a voter, I know I should follow instructions, but as a cashier, I’ve just spent hours managing lines and frustrated people, always trying to make things easier for them. Now, I’m the one in line, and I feel the same frustration. I stand there, caught between following the rules and wanting a little kindness for myself.
